explanation of basic psychodynamic concepts psychodynamic psychotherapy psychodynamic psychotherapy makes use of a number of concepts regarding the characteristic workings of the mind under conditions of normality, neurosis, personality disorder and psychosomatic conditions. some of the main techniques used are: click on each technique to know more. therapeutic alliance free association interpretation of defense mechanisms interpretation of transference free association developed by freud as an alternative to hypnosis which was perceived as more fallible. patients are invited to relate whatever comes into their mind during the session and not to censor their thoughts. it is intended to help the patient learn more about what he/she thinks and feels in an atmosphere of non-judgemental curiosity and acceptance. neither the therapist nor the patient knows in advance where the conversation will lead but it produces material which matters greatly to the patient. therapeutic alliance the mutual collaboration between a therapist and patient to overcome the resistance that blocks change and the healing process. “we form a pact with each other, the sick ego promises us the most complete candor and we assure the patient of the strictest discretion and place at his service our experience in interpreting material that has been influenced by the unconscious. this pact constitutes the analytic situation.” (freud) key relationships during the course of development, children establish complex relationships with key people in their lives, especially with parents. these relationships include attachment and the meeting of a variety of needs which change over time. where needs are not fulfilled or when the relationship is broken, there is potential for repetition, avoidance of equivalent subsequent relationships through the phenomenon of transference. transference refers to the unconscious influence of past learning of traumatic interpersonal relationships on present emotional responses, behaviour and relationships. it usually stems from childhood and interferes with normal relationship and decision-making. in other words, a whole series of psychological experiences are revived, not as belonging to the past, but as applying to the person of the current e.g. the therapist. types of transference positive transference: predominant emotion is in favour of the therapist. negative transference: predominant emotion is hostility to the therapist (assuming in reality he/she does not deserve it). counter-transference: the therapist’s transference feelings toward the patient (may be negative or positive). unconscious mental mechanisms every person is actively engaged in mental processes (mainly unconscious) in order to maintain an emotional equilibrium under influence from internal impulses (e.g. sexual drive and aggression) and emotional demands from others. this is assisted by a number of mental mechanisms (almost exclusively unconscious). when used in moderation, they are essential to mental health. however if overused they can become pathological. there are specific mental mechanisms that are more often implicated in psychopathology and suggest greater anxiety being held back by more desperate and primitive defences. examples click on the "examples" button to know more. examples of defence mechanisms repression - unacceptable impulses etc. are rendered unconscious sublimation - primary emotions are converted and expressed in socially accepted terms e.g. aggression into competitive sport rationalisation - self-deceiving, apparently rational “explanations” for instinctual behavious denial - of a painful experience or some unacceptable aspect of oneself. commonly seen in the early phase of normal grief reactions reaction formation - means by which a repressed forbidden wish is expressed by its opposite e.g. voyeuristic urges expressed by anti-pornography militancy displacement - displacing an affect or behaviour from one person to whom it would be appropriate to another person or object identification - someone takes on large aspects of another’s personality including symptomatology avoidance - in an attempt to escape failure or feeling humiliated it is one of the objectives of psychotherapy to enable a person to be more aware of his/her characteristic maladaptive mechanisms and to change in the direction of a more adaptive use of mechanisms. projection - attribution of one’s own feelings or wishes on to someone else e.g. feeling persecuted by a boss whereas the hostility is one’s own dissociation - two or more mental processes co-exist without becoming integrated conversion - an emotional response to stress is converted into a physical symptom regression - a return to earlier childlike mental states also seen in normal people under stress

brief overview psychodynamic psychotherapy psychodynamic psychotherapy is a term that encompasses therapy of an analytical nature. it is a form of depth psychology that focuses on the unconscious and past experiences, to determine current behaviour. generally psychodynamic psychotherapists adhere to the theories and teaching of sigmund freud but it also draws upon techniques from a variety of sources, including the ideas of various other luminaries including carl jung and alfred adler. sigmund freud carl jung

introduction psychodynamic psychotherapy the patient is encouraged to talk about childhood relationships with parents and other significant people. the main focus is to reveal the unconscious content of the psyche in an effort to relieve psychic tension. the therapist must try to keep his/her own personality out of the picture and in essence becoming a blank canvas onto which the client can transfer and project deep feelings about themselves, parents and other significant players in their life. the therapist remains focused on the dynamics between the client and the therapist. psychodynamic therapy tends to be less intensive and briefer than psychoanalysis, and also relies more on the interpersonal relationship between client and therapist than do other forms of depth psychology. it is a focus that has been used in individual psychotherapy, group psychotherapy, family therapy, and to understand and work with institutional and organisational contexts.
overview of psychodynamic psychotherapy psychodynamic psychotherapy other names for psychodynamic psychotherapy psychoanalytic psychotherapy exploratory psychotherapy insight oriented therapy

psychodynamic psychotherapy psychodynamic psychotherapy goal - to bring unconscious conflict to awareness make client’s problem clear (elucidate) understand defense mechanisms and transference responses (see later) this leads to developing insight intellectually emotionally

interpretations psychodynamic psychotherapy these are hypotheses about unconscious motivations for actions, events or statements that could be considered by the patient. they should aid the collaborative process and not be considered as absolute truths. often worth introducing with ‘perhaps…’ with time patients should learn to interpret different events for themselves. it is important to consider the effects of the interpretation and observe for their reaction. remember - interpretations are an art and not a science and should be done gradually and not all at once

overview of psychodynamic psychotherapy psychodynamic psychotherapy general approach historical focus: interpretations or observations are based on the client’s history always based on the transference--patient/therapist relationship assumptions unconscious mind exists holds painful feelings we avoid through our defenses needs, drives and feelings motivate behavior therapists’ role: provide unconditional acceptance - to support the patient in all that he/she is, no matter what that might be i.e. in expressing whatever is inside, no matter what it is and what it might trigger in the therapist. to make interpretations duration/frequency months to years longer term: open-ended 1-3 x weekly brief therapy techniques growing 1 x week

be aware of confusing psychodynamic and psychoanalytic psychotherapies psychodynamic psychotherapy psychoanalysis repressed childhood conflicts, id content, ego activity bringing conflict to conscious awareness overcome neurosis focus = global and aims to understand origins more intensive psychodynamic less emphasis on sexual and aggressive drives less emphasis on unconscious information more emphasis on past relationships more focused

overview of psychodynamic psychotherapy psychodynamic psychotherapy differences in assumptions and focus psychoanalysis all adult problems can be traced back to childhood interaction of ego, superego, id has a greater focus psychodynamic offshoot of the psychoanalytic school interpretation is main tool
approach psychodynamic psychotherapy approach to your psychodynamic psychotherapy case

before starting your first case psychodynamic psychotherapy you might be daunted by the prospect of working with a patient within a psychodynamic framework for a year. it could seem to have little structure in comparison with routine psychiatric work and even shorter forms of psychotherapy. hopefully this module will help the understand the whole process a bit more.

what is the aim of the experience? psychodynamic psychotherapy the aim of both therapy cases is not to train psychiatrists to become psychotherapists but to use the educational vehicle of supervised therapy to develop the therapeutic attitude which they will employ and develop further in whichever branch of psychiatry they choose to specialise in. the experience of remaining with a patient over time and developing a relationship involves the doctor in developing a capacity to examine their emotional responses in a way that builds on what they have experienced in case presentations in a more limited way in the balint group.
case allocation psychodynamic psychotherapy you should contact your local psychotherapy tutor to discuss local balint group arrangements and case allocations.

tips on how to approach the therapy psychodynamic psychotherapy patients do not need to become extremely angry or upset and experience cathartic resolution of their problems. p it is unlikely that telling people what they are doing wrong in their lives is going to change the patterns of relating to others. p psychotherapy is a conversation allowing the patient to begin to understand their predicament. p through observing the relationship with the therapist patients can start to notice how they view and interact with other people. p psychotherapy helps in becoming aware of the internal world and the way patients see themselves and the world. p

tips on how to approach the therapy psychodynamic psychotherapy the experience of attending regularly and being listened to might be new to many patients. p it can be an anxiety provoking experience, especially in the initial stages of the therapy. p as a therapist you should try not to reassure nor antagonise, and withold from giving advice. p your role is more in observing the relationship and providing feedback on it to the patient. p the role is very different to the active role taken in everyday psychiatric practice. p

setting/session principles psychodynamic psychotherapy sessions should be timed, not cancelled by the therapist unless necessary and happen in the same place and same time every week. consistency of the environment eliminates other variables and allows to focus on what is being played out in the sessions and facilitates safe exploration of self.

the role of supervision psychodynamic psychotherapy it might feel uncomfortable to admit uncertainty over what one is supposed to be doing and how to interpret the content of the sessions. supervision should allow to put these into context and make sense of the interactions. it is also a good place to discuss the feeling generated within the therapist (counter transference).

useful resources psychodynamic psychotherapy introduction to psychotherapy: an outline of psychodynamic principles and practice. 4th edition. anthony bateman, dennis brown & jonathan pedder. routledge skills in psychodynamic counselling and psychotherapy. susan howard. sage publications there is also the internet: royal college of psychiatrists https://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/specialties/faculties/psychotherapy/training/psychodynamicpsychotherapy.aspx#links british psychoanalytic council http://www.psychoanalytic-council.org/ click on icon to reveal resources.

resistance psychodynamic psychotherapy patients either directly or indirectly oppose changing their behaviour or refuse to discuss, remember or think about relevant experiences “the discovery of the unconsciousness and the introduction of it into conscousness is performed in the face of a continuos resistance on the part of the patient. the process of bringing this unconscious material to light is associated with pain and because of this pain the patient again and again rejects it ” (freud). examples may include: talk less late for appointments discuss trivial matters intensification of symptoms abatement of symptoms (“flights into health”) resistance in therapy most therapists try to work with resistance as a way to understand their patient better i.e. to work with the resistance and not against it. one example of this is using counter transference as a tool to understand the resistance - the feelings evoked in the therapist from the resistance will give you a hint of what the resistance is about

case progress psychodynamic psychotherapy click on each tab to know more. every therapy has to end. the aim is not to completely ‘cure’ the patient. it would be very difficult with some of the complex patients referred to psychotherapy departments. a more realistic approach is to aim at improvement in symptoms and ways of managing the distress. it is achieved not by concrete strategies, like in other types of therapy, but rather by developing capacity to reflect and understant self better. the long case usually finishes after a year or about 40 sessions. it is a good idea to discuss the end of therapeutic reltionship at least few sessions in advance, it often provides new, interesting insights. during the sessions all the spoken information is being considered together with silence, interactions and even absences. you need to try to observe the relatonships as it develops and feed it back to the patient. try not to fix or cure the patient, but rather assisst them in understanding themselves. the patients should be encouraged to say whatever is on their mind and the therapist’s role is to help to interpret what that means. the therapist is trying to understand as much as possible about the patient’s life. it is a patient led, collaborative approach, however you should be alert to what the patiet is saying and try to understand the underlying meaning, considering the impact of what is being discussed and roles taken on by patient and therapist.

core curriculum introduction the core curriculum for postgraduate training in psychiatry has been established by the royal college of psychiatrists. regarding psychotherapy competencies by ct3 level, a minimum of the following is required: complete a psychotherapy ace attend a minimum of 30 case based discussion groups over 2 years (aka balint group) undertake two psychotherapy cases in two modalities and over two durations between years st1 and st3 1 2 3

how to use this e-learning package introduction this gentle introduction will take you through some of the practical aspect of your preparation along with some basic theory for two of the more common psychotherapeutic approaches - cognitive behavioural therapy and psychodynamic psychotherapy as such, this package is not designed to be comprehensive by any stretch of the imagination and you should learn more about all psychotherapeutic approaches during your mrcpsych course, exam preparation and personal study. the package is split into two main parts, each focusing on a different psychotherapy (cbt and psychodynamic psychotherapy -the two most common approaches you will encounter) there are a number videos to accompany the written material which include scripted clinical scenarios, so you can see for yourself how each of the approaches may look in practice. we hope that you find it a useful companion to your preparation for your first psychotherapy case. please can you complete the feedback at the end to help us improve the package.

case based discussion/balint groups introduction for the majority of trainees, balint groups are likely to be your initial experience of psychodynamic thinking. they involve a regular weekly meetings of local trainees and a group facilitator usually lasting between 60 - 90minutes. the discussions usually focus on a clinical case from a psychotherapeutic point of view, paying attention to the emotional and cognitive aspects of assessment and management. trainees are encouraged to share their feelings and thoughts openly and to relfect on their interactions with patients. from the practical point of view: the balint groups could involve long periods of uncomfortable silence if no one is willing to volunteer to present a case. it is worth refreshing some of the history and reflecting on the case prior to the discussion. it is good practice to let your facilitator know in advance if you are not able to attend. make sure you contact the psychotherapy department to find out information about your local balint group.

what is the balint group experience for? introduction the aim of the balint group is to provide a supportive space for doctors’ encountering psychiatric work for the first time to think about their own emotional experience in relation to the mental and emotional disturbance they may encounter. the aim is to foster recognition that a therapeutic attitude to reflection on all psychiatric work can be of value in helping the doctor to manage extreme mental states and anxieties. as a core trainee beginning a balint group being prepared to acknowledge the fear associated with being in the on call situation and burdened in isolation with risk without feeling this makes one a weak or incompetent doctor would be an achievement.

basic concepts cognitive behavioural therapy cognitive behavioural theory was established to help explain depression the theory proposed that low mood was related to negative thoughts and to inactivity the model has since been applied to many anxiety disorders, to psychosis and to many physical complaints

beck 1960s - cognitive therapy cognitive behavioural therapy the basic notion is that how an individual interprets life events will determine their response to them. a tendency for some people to be especially negative in their beliefs and to use maladaptive information processing strategies. cognitive therapy aims to help people identify their beliefs and information processing styles and to systematically test their accuracy. aaron beck

basic concepts cognitive behavioural therapy the theory suggests that mood, thinking and actions all interact. the model adopts a scientific approach to both theory and therapy thoughts, beliefs, opinions, interpretations and appraisals are all seen as hypotheses or possibilities hypotheses can be reviewed and tested against new information

characteristics of cbt cognitive behavioural therapy focuses on solving problems - here and now problems helps patients to identify problems and to solve them focuses in on specific problems (not general complaints) aims to enable the patient to be their own therapist (learning beyond therapy) homework is essential - extends your capabilities way beyond therapy sessions therapy follows an overlapping sequence of: engagement assessment formulation treatment evaluation

a first session - could easily include……. cognitive behavioural therapy set agenda review presenting problem check mood establish goals educate about basic cognitive behavioural ideas expectations of therapy summarise findings educate about a particular disorder homework - have they written it down themselves? any feedback? therapist is busy and structured

cognitive therapy assessment cognitive behavioural therapy assessment of the following is essential: specific thoughts and images the meaning of those thoughts and images the assumptions and beliefs underlying those thoughts and images this is an ongoing information gathering exercise assessment leads to hypotheses…… ……which lead to a shared formulation…… ……which leads to a treatment plan…… ……which provides new information for review and integration into the formulation……

formulation (or case conceptualisation) cognitive behavioural therapy if you were to observe a cognitive therapist assessing and formulating you would see……………. summarising collaboration socratic questioning explicit linking of cognition, emotion and behaviour in order to explain what keeps the problem going and to some limited extent where the problem comes from establishing goals treatment planning what is a formulation? the combining of clinical information and the theoretical model (in this case the cognitive model) what must a formulation do? it must explain the development and maintenance of a problem it must help a client connect seemingly unconnected behaviours, thoughts and emotions

what must a formulation do? cognitive behavioural therapy it must be explanatory, explainable, normalising, non-judgmental and highly individualised it must be an alternative version of events it must emphasise the interacting roles of emotion, thought and behaviour in the problem most importantly……………………. the formulation is the focal point for all change hence…………………. the formulation must lead to a treatment plan at the end of a good assessment session(s) a client should have a formulation and a treatment plan the therapist should also have this formulation and treatment plan and should be able to easily explain it to others

how to successfully set an agenda at the start of a session cognitive behavioural therapy cbt is structured we will plan each session we will make an agenda at the beginning and keep on track to make sure we achieve our goals we will work together as a collaborative team to understand how your feelings, thoughts and behaviours interact to maintain the problem

agenda setting (and sticking to it) cognitive behavioural therapy agenda setting points to include: therapist to lead the beginning of the session therapist to summarise work so far (across sessions) therapist to re-orientate to where the work is up to therapist to have pre-planned agenda items e.g. the creation of a formulation diagram a review of the formulation diagram - client to explain a review of any homework tasks set (e.g. behavioural experiments, reading, recording of information) to ask the client if they have any specific agenda items to decide if they need detailed work or if they are simply being mentioned/the therapist is being updated to value relevant items and to include them and work on them sticking to it establishing in first 3-5 minutes what the agenda will be establishing (approximately) how much time will be spent on each item too many items to do any of them justice? therapist takes responsibility for monitoring progress and time within the session - stop, review, get back on track

how to agree, set and review homework tasks in cognitive behavioural therapy cognitive behavioural therapy why set homework tasks? to expand your treatment beyond the limits of your sessions to foster behavioural changes in real life to foster the transfer of gains in-session to real life to find things out and gather information to test predictions and find out what is actually the case? to challenge specific negative thoughts………. i won’t be able to do it i won’t enjoy it i am too tired i don’t have the energy this is a waste of time to challenge therapist’s predictions about using and imposing structure, agendas, tasks and scary behavioural experiments

agreeing homework tasks cognitive behavioural therapy these should flow naturally and collaboratively from the session in early sessions tasks will derive from the assessment process tasks will also derive from a wish to gather new information from multiple sources as cbt progresses tasks will derive from the formulation and the treatment plan as treatment progresses many tasks will be behavioural experiments in a behavioural experiment you are exploring the situation in real life so some will occur as homework tasks agreeing homework tasks……..examples monitoring and recording thoughts, feelings and behaviours to establish patterns behavioural activation tasks reading (and underlining / highlighting the most relevant or pertinent sections) a full behavioural experiment planned in-session but executed as a homework task

setting homework tasks cognitive behavioural therapy collaboratively - you are not imposing or instructing the client must understand the rationale tasks should be written down ideally the client should write the tasks down (photocopy for your records) it should be planned that the task will definitely be reviewed the following session (on the agenda) a follow-up phone call between sessions is a useful tool reviewing homework tasks on the agenda in advance give the review process adequate time and attention - value it before reviewing progress clarify the rationale for why it was set in the first place patient to bring along the original homework plan (you bring your photocopy as a back-up) examine the learning points from the task - important what have we learnt? what are the logical consequences? what next?

managing the time in cbt sessions cognitive behavioural therapy cbt is structured - you are encouraged to say……………. ‘cbt is structured and we will plan each session, make an agenda at the beginning and keep on track to make sure we achieve our goals’ ‘we will work together as a collaborative team to understand how your feelings, thoughts and behaviours interact to maintain the problem’ ‘i will make sure we both keep on track with the work by summarising our progress as we go’

how to get the balance right? cognitive behavioural therapy if you get it right then…………………….. active listening and regular summaries show you are interested and have heard the client a formulation diagram shows that you have bothered to try to synthesise all the details writing things down shows that you take it seriously and want to understand

managing the time will be greatly aided by………agenda setting cognitive behavioural therapy we will plan each session we will make an agenda at the beginning and keep on track to make sure we achieve our goals

managing the time successfully - other factors….. cognitive behavioural therapy 1 how to make sure you finish on time? 2 how to avoid being your own worst enemy and allow yourself to get side-tracked? click on question buttons to know more. how to make sure you finish on time? start briskly so have time to spare (not rushing at end) don’t try to do too much in any one session don’t start something you can’t finish allow time for homework setting and feedback be open and explicit about noting the time throughout make sure you can both see the clock don’t allow things to drift and put yourself under time pressure towards the end never run over (don’t set a precedent) how to avoid being your own worst enemy and allow yourself to get side-tracked? are you sure this avenue is worth going down? is this just another example of something you both already understand or is this new and important information? will pursuing this mean missing an agenda item? are you and the client clear on the purpose of being side-tracked? be collaborative - stop - check that you both agree agree to come back to it - if it is really important you will come back to it

useful resources cognitive behavioural therapy cognitive therapy: basics and beyond. judith s. beck. guilford press cognitive behaviour therapy for psychiatric problems: a practical guide. keith hawton. oup oxford mind over mood: change how you feel by changing the way you think. dennis greenberger and christine padesky. guilford press there is also the internet: royal college of psychiatrists http://www.rcpsych.ac.uk/healthadvice/treatmentswellbeing/cbt.aspx british association for cognitive and behavioural therapies http://www.babcp.com click on icon to reveal resources.
